sink.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: to go down below the surface of water, mud etc
sink.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: Their motorboat struck a rock and began to sink.
The kids watched as the coin sank to the bottom of the pool.
The heavy guns sank up to their barrels in the mud.
sink.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: to damage a ship so badly that it sinks
sink.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: A luxury yacht was sunk in a bomb attack yesterday.
sink.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: to move downwards to a lower level
sink.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: The sun was sinking behind the coconut palms.
Her chin sank onto her chest, and she looked despairing.
sink.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: to fall down or sit down heavily, especially because you are very tired and weak
sink.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: The minister sank to his knees (=he went down into a kneeling position) and prayed.
She let out a groan and sank into a chair.
He let go of her shoulders and she sank at once to the floor.
Marion sank down on a rock, and wept.
sink.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: to gradually get into a worse condition
sink.translation[0].definitions[4].examp: The doctor said that the boy was sinking fast (=getting weaker and about to die).
They lost all their money and sank into desperate poverty.
The good mood left me and I sank into depression.
sink.translation[0].definitions[5].defin: to go down in amount or value
sink.translation[0].definitions[5].examp: Shares in the company have sunk as low as 620p.
The population of the village sank to just a few families.
sink.translation[0].definitions[6].defin: if your voice sinks, it becomes very quiet
sink.translation[0].definitions[6].examp: Her voice sank to a whisper.
sink.translation[0].definitions[7].defin: to put your teeth or something sharp into someoneâ€™s flesh, into food etc
sink.translation[0].definitions[7].examp: The dog sank its teeth into my arm.
She sank her fork into the pie.
sink.translation[0].definitions[8].defin: if you sink something such as a well or part of a building, you dig a hole to put it into the ground
sink.translation[0].definitions[8].examp: A well was sunk in the back garden, and water could be pumped up into the kitchen.
sink.translation[0].definitions[9].defin: to spend a lot of money on something
sink.translation[0].definitions[9].examp: They sank their entire savings into their house.
sink.translation[0].definitions[10].defi: to put a ball into a hole or basket in games such as golf or basketball
sink.translation[0].definitions[11].defi: to drink alcohol, especially in large quantities
sink.translation[0].definitions[11].exam: We sank a few pints at the pub first.
sink.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: a large open container that you fill with water and use for washing yourself, washing dishes etc
